An Emergency Response Program has been developed to respond to any chlorine release scenario. Emergency response actions involve the system operators and maintenance staff, the Base Fire Department, and offsite expertise from the San Diego County Hazardous Incident Response Team (HIRT), when necessary. In addition, the Assistant Chief of Staff (AC/S), Environmental Security (Env Scty) or an appointed representative serves as the focal point for notifying the appropriate agencies and providing information to the public.

1.2 STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED
Chlorine stored in 150-pound cylinders is used for disinfection at both water supply and wastewater treatment facilities under Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program Level 1. A process is eligible for Program Level 1 if the process has not had any California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP)-defined accidents in the past five years (see in Section 4.0), if the worst-case release scenario (defined in Section 5.0) does not impact any public receptors, and if emergency response efforts are coordinated with outside responding agencies. Table 1-1 identifies the Program Level 1 chlorine facilities at MCB Camp Pendleton, provides a description of the process, and lists the maximum amount of chlorine in the system. No new sites were added since the last RMP update. Facilities that have been removed from the revised RMP are listed in Table 1-2. Other chlorine facilities that exist at MCB Camp Pendleton are described in two additional RMP Public Documents ? Program Levels 2 and 3.

1.3 WORST-CASE RELEASE SCENARIO(S) AND ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO(S)
The site-specific worst-case release analysis and alternative release scenario are on file at MCB Camp Pendleton.

1.4 GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND THE SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS
MCB Camp Pendleton has taken steps so that the chlorine systems comply with EPA?s Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with applicable state codes and regulations. The buildings containing the systems have been evaluated against NFPA 55 and the Uniform Building Code. As a result, several system or building upgrades are being planned or considered (see Section 1.7 for more details).
Although not required by CalARP regulations, MCB Camp Pendleton has developed a prevention program that includes:
* Documenting process safety information regarding the hazards of chlorine and components of the system;
* Conducting a process hazard analysis to evaluate potential mechanical failures or operational causes that could result in an accidental release;
* Implementing written operating procedures;
* Implementing a training program;
* Implementing a preventive maintenance program;
* Conduc

ting incident investigation; and
* Conducting compliance audits.

1.5 FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
CalARP regulations require facilities to compile a five-year accident history. This is defined as ?all accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in death, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage? (California Code of Regulations [CCR], Title 19, Chapter 4.5, Section 2750.9). According to information provided by the Base Fire Department AC/S, Env Scty, there have been no accidental releases from the Program Level 1 chlorine systems that meet the above definition since the original RMP was issued on 21 June 1999.

1.6 EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
The Emergency Response Program is based on the existing management system (see Appendix A) for responding to emergencies, the appropriate discovery and notification procedures, and coordination with the San Diego County HIRT. The operators and maintenance staff from the Facilities Maintenance Department (FMD) have been trained as Facilities Responders to report accidental releases to the Base Fire Department. The Base Fire Department subsequently notifies HIRT for emergency response actions if needed. The AC/S, Env Scty plays an active role in notifying the appropriate government agencies and communicating releases to the public.
